original_data.question: Two hours after admission to the hospital for rupture of membranes, a 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 40 weeks’ gestation is evaluated for the sudden onset of chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension. The patient successfully underwent combined spinal-epidural anesthesia 1 hour ago. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated with the exception of a positive vaginal swab for group B streptococci 3 weeks ago, for which she received one dose of intravenous penicillin. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Physical examination shows labored breathing and thready pulses. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The abdomen is nontender. Speculum examination shows pooling of bright red blood in the cervical canal. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7.6 mg/dL and an undetectable fibrinogen concentration. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?

options.A: Apical ballooning of the left ventricle
options.B: Amniotic fluid entering the endocervical veins
options.C: Anesthetic agent entering the subarachnoid space

model_response:
The patient has suffered a rare but catastrophic complication of labor, amniotic fluid embolism. This condition is characterized by the entry of fetal tissues, cells, and fluids into the maternal circulation. Amniotic fluid enters the uterine veins via the placental site, bypassing the lungs. The fetal cells trigger a profound maternal inflammatory response, with release of thromboplastin and consumption of procoagulants, particularly fibrinogen. The end result is disseminated intravascular coagulation. The initial presentation is usually sudden onset of respiratory distress, hypotension, and cyanosis during labor or within 2 hours after delivery. The classic triad of symptoms is hypoxia, hypotension, and coagulopathy. The diagnosis is clinical. Treatment is supportive, with attention to oxygenation, blood pressure, and coagulopathy. The mortality rate is 80%.

Amniotic fluid embolism should be distinguished from pulmonary embolism of amniotic fluid. In this condition, the patient develops profound respiratory distress during labor or in the immediate postpartum period. The diagnosis is usually made with echocardiography, which shows an abrupt decrease in right ventricular return and ejection. This condition is uniformly fatal.

Apical ballooning of the left ventricle is a feature of peripartum cardiomyopathy, which is a dilated cardiomyopathy that occurs in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months of delivery. Patients present with congestive heart failure. Anesthetic agent entering the subarachnoid space is a rare but potentially fatal complication of spinal or epidural anesthesia. It usually occurs with accidental intrathecal injection of a large volume of anesthetic agent. The classic presentation is a high spinal block, with hypotension, bradycardia, and respiratory insufficiency. Systemic bacterial infection is a common cause of spontaneous abortion in the first trimester. It usually presents with fever, chills, and malodorous vaginal discharge.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
**Description:**The patient has been admitted to a care facility and their community medications are suspended until hospital discharge.
Institutions with an organized medical staff which provide medical care to patients.
Forcible or traumatic tear or break of an organ or other soft part of the body.
Thin layers of tissue which cover parts of the body, separate adjacent cavities, or connect adjacent structures.
Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
The number of offspring a female has borne. It is contrasted with GRAVIDITY, which refers to the number of pregnancies, regardless of outcome.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The start of an event or episode that is characterized as occurring suddenly or at a relatively short period of time after a reference time.
Difficult or labored breathing.
A mental state characterized by bewilderment, emotional disturbance, lack of clear thinking, and perceptual disorientation.

Abnormally low BLOOD PRESSURE that can result in inadequate blood flow to the brain and other vital organs. Common symptom is DIZZINESS but greater negative impacts on the body occur when there is prolonged depravation of oxygen and nutrients.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Procedure in which an anesthetic is injected directly into the spinal cord.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
Respond with exceptions only
Involving advantage or good.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.

Administration of a drug within or into a vein or veins. Introduction of the drug directly into venous circulation results in 100% bioavailability due to an absence of the absorption phase, provides a precise and continuous mode of drug therapy, especially for drugs with a narrow therapeutic index.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
A non-invasive method that provides estimates of arterial oxyhemoglobin saturation by utilizing selected wavelengths of light to determine the saturation of oxyhemoglobin.
Unmodified air as existing in the immediate surroundings.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Weak or absent palpable pulse due to decreased arterial pulse pressure.
Abnormal breath sounds (crackles) heard on auscultation, indicating inflammation, fluid, or infection of the lung.
A condition in which a person partially loses the ability to hear sounds in one or both ears.
The bottom concave portion of the lung that is situated on the convexity of the diaphragm.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Combine together into a single unit, group, or sample.
The passage of fresh blood from the anus. The blood is usually seen in the stools. The most common cause is lower gastrointestinal tract hemorrhage.
The neck portion of the UTERUS between the lower isthmus and the VAGINA forming the cervical canal.
An extract of Goa powder; a complex mixture of reduction products of chrysophanic acid, emodin, and emodin monomethyl ether; used locally in ringworm, psoriasis, and eczema.
The act or process of concentrating, focusing the attention and mental energy on a single object to the exclusion of others.
The act or process of concentrating, focusing the attention and mental energy on a single object to the exclusion of others.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
